title.value: Interpretable deep learning architectures for improving drug response prediction performance: myth or reality?
title.justification: The title is explicitly mentioned in the document.
title.quote: Interpretable deep learning architectures for improving drug response prediction performance: myth or reality?

extractions.description: This paper investigates the performance of interpretable deep learning models in drug response prediction, comparing them with non-interpretable models, and assessing the impact of incorporating pathway information.

type.justification: The paper includes a comprehensive assessment of different deep learning models and experimental evaluation using various data.
type.quote: We comprehensively and systematically assessed four state-of-the-art interpretable DL models using three pathway collections to assess their ability in making accurate predictions.

name.justification: The primary focus of the paper is on applying deep learning to drug response prediction, a typical bioinformatics application.
name.quote: Interpretable deep learning (DL) models that can provide biological insights, in addition to accurate predictions, are of great interest to the biomedical community.

name.justification: The paper specifically evaluates models for predicting drug response.
name.quote: interpreter DL models that incorporate signaling pathways have been proposed for drug response prediction (DRP).

name.justification: The paper discusses PathDNN as one of the interpretable models evaluated.
name.quote: we selected four pathway-based state-of-the-art models: PathDNN (Deng et al. 2020), CDS (Zhang et al. 2021a), HiDRA (Jin and Nam 2021), and PathDSP (Tang and Gottlieb 2021).

is_contributed.justification: PathDNN is referenced as one of the state-of-the-art models evaluated in the study, not contributed.
is_contributed.quote: we selected four pathway-based state-of-the-art models: PathDNN (Deng et al. 2020)

is_executed.justification: PathDNN is executed as part of the experiments conducted in the study.
is_executed.quote: we selected four pathway-based state-of-the-art models

is_compared.justification: The performance of PathDNN is compared with other models in the study.
is_compared.quote: PathDNN and other models were benchmarked.

referenced_paper_title.value: Pathway-guided deep neural network toward interpretable and predictive modeling of drug sensitivity
referenced_paper_title.justification: PathDNN is associated with the referenced paper by Deng et al., which introduced this model.

name.justification: ConsDeepSignaling is explicitly named as one of the models evaluated.
name.quote: We selected four pathway-based state-of-the-art models: PathDNN (Deng et al. 2020), CDS (Zhang et al. 2021a)...

is_contributed.justification: ConsDeepSignaling is referenced as one of the state-of-the-art models, not newly proposed by this paper.
is_contributed.quote: we selected four pathway-based state-of-the-art models: PathDNN (Deng et al. 2020), CDS (Zhang et al. 2021a)

is_executed.justification: ConsDeepSignaling is one of the models analyzed in experiments.
is_executed.quote: We selected these models since they use similar type of information for CCLs and drugs and utilize geneâ€“pathway membership in their architectures.

is_compared.justification: The performance of ConsDeepSignaling is compared against other models.
is_compared.quote: Our analysis showed...comparable to those of the interpretable models.

referenced_paper_title.value: Predicting anticancer drug response with deep learning constrained by signaling pathways
referenced_paper_title.justification: This model is linked to the referenced paper by Zhang et al., which covers ConsDeepSignaling.

name.justification: HiDRA is specifically mentioned as one of the interpretable models evaluated in the study.
name.quote: We selected four pathway-based state-of-the-art models: PathDNN (Deng et al. 2020), CDS (Zhang et al. 2021a), HiDRA (Jin and Nam 2021)...

is_contributed.justification: HiDRA is cited as a pre-existing state-of-the-art model, not newly introduced in this paper.
is_contributed.quote: We selected four pathway-based state-of-the-art models:... HiDRA (Jin and Nam 2021)

is_executed.justification: HiDRA is used in the experiments conducted in this study.
is_executed.quote: We tested all models using the three pathway collections discussed earlier.

is_compared.justification: HiDRA's performance is evaluated in relation to other models.
is_compared.quote: The analysis showed that implicit models generally performed better in predicting unseen CCLs and unseen pairs...

referenced_paper_title.value: HiDRA: hierarchical network for drug response prediction with attention
referenced_paper_title.justification: HiDRA is related to the referenced work by Jin and Nam focusing on drug response prediction.

name.justification: The paper lists PathDSP as one of the models assessed.
name.quote: We selected four pathway-based state-of-the-art models: PathDNN (Deng et al. 2020), CDS (Zhang et al. 2021a), HiDRA (Jin and Nam 2021), and PathDSP (Tang and Gottlieb 2021).

is_contributed.justification: PathDSP is recognized as a state-of-the-art model from prior research.
is_contributed.quote: We selected four pathway-based state-of-the-art models:... PathDSP (Tang and Gottlieb 2021)

is_executed.justification: PathDSP is included as part of the model evaluation experiments.
is_executed.quote: We tested all models using the three pathway collections discussed earlier.

is_compared.justification: The performance of PathDSP is evaluated in comparison to other models.
is_compared.quote: PathDSP (GEx, T) outperformed all models in LCO and LPO data splitting schemes.

referenced_paper_title.value: Explainable drug sensitivity prediction through cancer pathway enrichment
referenced_paper_title.justification: This model is linked to the referenced paper by Tang and Gottlieb.

name.justification: Used as a baseline for comparison with deep learning models.
name.quote: random forests (RF) baseline was comparable to those of the interpretable models.

is_contributed.justification: Random Forests is used as a baseline model, not contributed by this paper.
is_contributed.quote: random forests (RF) baseline was comparable to those of the interpretable models.

is_executed.justification: Random Forests is executed as a baseline comparison model in this study.
is_executed.quote: We tested all models using the three pathway collections discussed earlier.

is_compared.justification: Random Forests is compared to other models as a baseline.
is_compared.quote: random forests baseline was comparable to those of the interpretable models.

referenced_paper_title.justification: Random Forests is a standard model not specific to a single research paper.
referenced_paper_title.quote: We comprehensively and systematically assessed... and the performance of a random forests baseline was comparable to those of the interpretable models.

name.justification: MLP is specifically mentioned as part of the experiment as a non-interpretable model.
name.quote: best performance was achieved using a black-box multilayer perceptron

is_contributed.justification: MLP is a standard deep learning model used for comparison.

is_executed.justification: MLP is tested as an experimental comparison model.
is_executed.quote: We comprehensively and systematically assessed... and the performance of a random forests baseline was comparable to those of the interpretable models.

is_compared.justification: MLP is used as a comparison to assess the performance of interpretable models.
is_compared.quote: the performance of a random forests baseline was comparable to those of the interpretable models. Moreover, even in instances that performance improvement...

referenced_paper_title.justification: MLP is a widely used model not attributed to a single specific paper.
referenced_paper_title.quote: A black-box multilayer perceptron was used as a baseline.

name.value: Genomics of Drug Sensitivity in Cancer (GDSC)
name.justification: GDSC is mentioned as one of the primary datasets used in the experiments.
name.quote: collected GEx, Mut, CNV, and drug sensitivity data (in the form of log IC50) of 959 CCLs from Genomics of Drug Sensitivity in Cancer (GDSC)

referenced_paper_title.value: A resource for therapeutic biomarker discovery in cancer cells.
referenced_paper_title.justification: GDSC references a known source, not limited to a specific contributing paper for this study.
referenced_paper_title.quote: collected GEx, Mut, CNV, and drug sensitivity data... from Genomics of Drug Sensitivity in Cancer (GDSC) (Yang et al. 2013) database.

name.justification: CCLE is addressed as an additional dataset for cross-validation of predictions.
name.quote: we also assessed the generalizability of the DL models by performing a cross-dataset analysis... we used their GEx profile from the Cancer Cell Line Encyclopedia (CCLE)

referenced_paper_title.value: The Cancer Cell Line Encyclopedia enables predictive modelling of anticancer drug sensitivity.
referenced_paper_title.justification: The dataset is referred to in the context of enabling predictive modeling, corroborating its source study.
referenced_paper_title.quote: we used their GEx profile from the Cancer Cell Line Encyclopedia (CCLE) (Barretina et al. 2012).
